Author: dollyvolley
Content: How can one maintain the machine? Is it possible to update the system while its deployed (e.g. via an upgrade command)

Author: carsten.munk
Content: so in general you can replace a flash drive in a state snapshot, but you also need to think of it in terms of how a linux kernel reacts to a disk drive being replaced without proper mounting/unmounting

Author: max_h
Content:
Thanks for the updates on the Compute R&D channel @Carsten | Zippie! I'm quite curious (and excited) about these two experimental plans:

> - To prototype a EigenLayer AVS that is slashable based on a Compute result
> - Get a Cartesi Machine memory image backed RiscZero ZK proof of a Cartesi Machine working with a few (big machine) cycles

Can you shed more light on EigenLayer AVS? Do you see this as the best option to spin up & bootstrap compute validators (given restaking/ability to tap into eth validators & stake)? Do you think this could also be beneficial for Cartesi Rollups?

Author: carsten.munk
Content:
Right now it's mostly skill-up so we understand where the walls are there. I think AVS'es will help in:
- Sequencing
- Short term provable message busses (like, for arbitration verification games happening off-chain in a high security manner)
- Data availability
- Possible staking models around compute validators
- Better ways to bridge and do L2<->L2 stuff
- Better sync committes than Ethereum L1 itself provides since they're actually slashable

Author: carsten.munk
Content: it's one of those a bit where i think there's potential and a lot of blind spots to where it can help verified computation

Author: carsten.munk
Content: will share all learnings here on discord and/or blogs, naturally, as things progress - think in 2024 ethereum-based systems likely are completely unrecognisable from what we see today so, because of tech like these

Author: max_h
Content: Thanks for the insights and yea will definitely keep an eye out for your writings haha! This seems super promising and I can definitely imagine that it might shake up and change up some of the systems we have today

Author: carsten.munk
Content: i'm just looking forward to have to spend less time with the EVM ğŸ˜‚

Author: carsten.munk
Content: ah, also, DKG's at mass scale

Author: max_h
Content: Can you elaborate on this one?

Author: carsten.munk
Content: basically a bit like how dfinity does it, it has a single ICP public key, because there was a distributed key generation process across all nodes so each have a shard of the 'private key' but nobody ever has the whole private key; so you can ask a certain threshold of the nodes to sign for you and it adds up as if the "private key" signed it

Author: carsten.munk
Content: it's useful for a lot of things such as conditional decryption and so forth

Author: carsten.munk
Content: https://litprotocol.com/ is probably what comes close atm

Author: max_h
Content: Very interesting!

Author: carsten.munk
Content: One thing I never really tested is how itâ€™s exactly handled in compute when something does a yield - if itâ€™s seen as end of execution (that you then can continue on in a second run based on the resulting machine hash)

Author: carsten.munk
Content: Yield is a bit like stopping the machine but itâ€™s continuable, for example, for replacing a flash drive in between

Author: erickdemoura
Content: I don't know exactly what you are trying to achieve, but it is right to assume that Cartesi Rollups (unlike Cartesi Compute) is a continuous/stateful VM. Transactions go to L1 or a sequencer in L2 (if you use Cartesi as L3) and the VM updates its state accordingly.

Author: erickdemoura
Content: Then from time to time the validator nodes make a claim on-chain with a hash that represents the VM state.

Author: diego.nehab
Content: The manual yield creates a fixed point in the machine, a trap, from which the machine cannot escape unless it is released from the outside.

Author: diego.nehab
Content: From the point of view or arbitration in compute, it is just as if the machine was halted.

Author: diego.nehab
Content: You can, however, take that machine, "unhalt it" and give it whatever input it needs to continue running, and start a new compute stage.

Author: diego.nehab
Content: This is the basis for "rollups".

Author: diego.nehab
Content: These transitions from a fixed state to a runnable state are doable with a few surgeries using hashes, or directly on the machine using a few entrypoints.

Author: diego.nehab
Content: You could treat a manually yielded machine (iflags_Y set) just like you treat a halted machine (iflags_H set) for the purpose of compute, I think. Or you could consider it an error and bail.

Author: erickdemoura
Content: Also, in regard to your privacy requirement, the discussion you had previously with Carsten about permissioned nodes applies to rollups as well.

Author: dollyvolley
Content: Thanks a lot @erickdemoura! Is there no option to submit the transactions directly to the nodes? Because if they go via L1 then the privacy is not given

Author: carsten.munk
Content: @diego.nehab mostly out of idle curiousity, why the separate rollup/voucher/etc buffers and not go through flash drives? kernel / caching gotchas?

Author: diego.nehab
Content: They are just memory ranges that the kernel can access.

Author: diego.nehab
Content: Flash drives load a driver for mtd (we will replace it with another driver later on) and get exposed as an mtd device and an associated block device.

Author: diego.nehab
Content: We didn't want processes to access these memory ranges in random ways.

Author: diego.nehab
Content: So we created an API for rollups and only the rollup driver can access these memory ranges.

Author: diego.nehab
Content: Felt cleaner this way.

Author: erickdemoura
Content:
I see. If data availability is given by the blockchain (or L2), then you could consider sending encrypted input. 
In your case, you may not need hard DA assumptions. Perhaps you could use IPFS and only store the hashes on-chain. Or some customization of the rollups nodes to receive and retain data themselves.

Author: erickdemoura
Content: Then it's really up to the security and availability guarantees you want to work with.
